item.title: Chinese Authorities Question Metals Bosses in Smuggling Probe
item.description: Chinese authorities have questioned the heads of some of the country’s leading metals merchants and producers as part of an intensifying effort to crack down on critical-minerals smuggling, according to people familiar with the situation.
item.dc:creator: Julian Luk, Alfred Cang

item.title: Bank Indonesia Poised to Resume Rate Cuts as Growth Falters
item.description: Indonesia’s central bank is expected to resume lowering interest rates as the US-China trade truce and the rupiah’s ensuing rebound open up a window of opportunity for policymakers to spur economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing

media:content.media:description: The Bank Indonesia headquarters beyond the traffic in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Wednesday, Sept. 18, 2024. Indonesia’s central bank is approaching the point where it can start easing borrowing costs as the rupiah keeps strengthening and inflation stays modest. Most economists aren’t convinced that it will happen this week though, before the expected US rate cut.

item.title: G-7 Countries Discuss Tariffs on Low-Value Chinese Products
item.description: Canadian Finance Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne said Group of Seven countries have started discussing tariffs on oversupplied, low-value Chinese products.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg, Brian Platt, Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Francois-Philippe Champagne Photographer: Cole Burston/Bloomberg

item.title: US Sets the Stage for Duties on Battery Materials From China
item.description: The US Commerce Department set the stage for anti-subsidy duties on imports of key battery components from China, after concluding materials had been unfairly subsidized.
item.dc:creator: Tope Alake

item.title: G-7 Finance Ministers Aim to Avoid Public Spats With US Despite Trade Turmoil
item.description: Finance ministers who’ve gathered in Canada for a Group of Seven meeting this week face a difficult task — trying to find common ground on trade issues while avoiding public conflict with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Erik Hertzberg, Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Tourists take photos with the Banff town sign, ahead of the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors' Meeting in Banff, Alberta, Canada on May 20, 2025. Top finance leaders from the G7 nations gather in Canada starting Tuesday, with concerns including war in Ukraine at the fore while the advanced economies grapple with fallout from US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs. (Photo by Cole Burston / AFP) (Photo by COLE BURSTON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: China-US Trade Soars as Exporters Race to Hit Trade Truce Window
item.description: A temporary trade truce between the world’s two largest economies has sparked a knee-jerk bounce across China’s ports and factory floors.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Katia Dmitrieva, Weilun Soon

item.title: China Ran Record Budget Deficit With Spending Blitz Amid Tariffs
item.description: China’s fiscal stimulus pushed its four-month budget deficit to a record high, as the government ramped up support for the economy during an escalation in its trade conflict with the US.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Fran Wang

item.title: Japan’s Farm Minister Quits Over Rice Gaffe in Hit to Ishiba
item.description: Japan’s farm minister quit Wednesday after saying he’s never needed to buy rice, a comment that fueled criticism of Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s minority government and its handling of rising food prices ahead of an election.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Yuko Takeo

media:content.media:description: Taku Eto, center, at the parliament in Tokyo on May 19.

item.title: Japan’s Exports Slow as US Tariffs Bite, Risking Recession
item.description: Growth in Japan’s exports slowed as the US ramped up its tariff measures, highlighting the risks the country faces after its economy already contracted before the levies began hitting in earnest.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: South Korean Early May Exports Fall as Shipments to US Slump
item.description: South Korea’s early trade data showed exports falling again this month especially to the US as negotiations between Seoul and Washington continue over tariffs on shipments from the Asian nation.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

item.title: Fed’s Daly, Hammack Stress Wait-And-See Policy Approach
item.description: Two Federal Reserve officials underscored the US central bank can be patient and assess incoming data before adjusting policy as the economy navigates heightened uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: Mary Daly Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Reeves to Meet Bessent as Questions Linger Over UK-US Deal
item.description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves will hold talks with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent this week, as the two countries continue to finalize the details of an agreement to cut tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump’s administration.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer.

item.title: South Africa’s Budget Gets Third Reboot With Credibility on Line
item.description: South African Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana’s third attempt to deliver a budget represents his sternest test yet.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana, S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Enoch Godongwana, South Africa's finance minister, center, speaks to the press after presenting the revised 2025 Budget at the National Assembly in Cape Town, South Africa, on Wednesday, March 12, 2025. Godongwana and his National Treasury officials were sent back to the drawing board last month after his revenue and spending plan failed to get buy-in from parties.

item.title: Sanctions Risk Pushing Russia Away From Talks, Rubio Says
item.description: President Donald Trump thinks Russia will likely walk away from Ukraine peace talks if the US threatens more sanctions, according to his top diplomat, supporting the White House’s decision not to pressure Moscow despite its resistance to a ceasefire.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin, Natalia Drozdiak

media:content.media:description: Senator Marco Rubio, a Republican from Florida and US secretary of state nominee for US President-elect Donald Trump, during a Senate Foreign Relations Committee confirmation hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Jan. 15, 2025. The top Republican and Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee joined in praising Rubio at the Florida senator's nomination hearing for secretary of state, signaling he'll face one of the easiest confirmations of President-elect Donald Trump's cabinet.

item.title: Fed’s Musalem Says Tariffs Will Likely Weigh on Growth, Jobs
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis President Alberto Musalem said tariffs will likely weigh on the US economy and weaken the labor market.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Alberto Musalem, St. Louis Fed president

item.title: Australia's Rare Feat on Inflation, Jobs May Hold Lessons for Other Economies
item.description: Through the post-Covid cost-of-living crisis, Australia’s central bank took a gentler approach than global peers to reining in inflation, managing to keep the economy close to full employment throughout — a rare feat that’s sparked debate about its viability as a model to tackle future crises.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Customers at Carriageworks Farmers Market in Sydney, Australia, on Saturday, April 26, 2025. Australia is scheduled to release consumer price index (CPI) figures on April 30.

item.title: Brazil Finance Chief Pivots as Lula Lingers in the Limelight
item.description: Not long ago, Brazil’s finance chief was a rising star in the government of President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Now, factors beyond Fernando Haddad’s control have put his political ambitions on hold.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck, Simone Iglesias

media:content.media:description: Fernando Haddad

item.title: Influx of Foreign-Born Workers Drove 2024 US Labor Force Growth
item.description: Foreign-born workers drove US labor force growth for another year in 2024, providing a last boost for the job market before President Donald Trump’s immigration crackdown was set in motion.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Contractors raise a framed wall at the Toll Brothers Redwood, a 55 years of age and up active adult community, in Folsom, California, US, on Thursday, March 6, 2025. The US Census Bureau is scheduled to release housing starts figures on March 18.

item.title: New Zealand Set to Deliver Tight Budget as Economic Outlook Dims
item.description: New Zealand Finance Minister Nicola Willis will keep a tight rein on spending in this week’s budget as uncertainty about global growth holds back a domestic recovery and restrains government revenue.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

media:content.media:description: Nicola Willis, New Zealand's finance minister, during a Bloomberg Television interview in Sydney, Australia, on Friday, Feb. 23, 2024. Willis has cast doubt on her ability to return the budget to surplus by 2027, saying the weakening economy is likely to impact on tax revenue. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

item.title: Romania to Weigh Rate Cuts When Politics and Markets Calm
item.description: Romania will weigh further interest-rate cuts only after a return to market and political stability, the central bank chief said, as the election of a centrist candidate to the presidency on Sunday spurred preparations to form a new government.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: Mugur Isarescu Photographer: Andreas Arnold/Bloomberg

item.title: Musk Says He’s Pushing Ahead With OpenAI Lawsuit

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Wunsch Says Economy May Need Some Support From Rates
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Pierre Wunsch said the euro-zone economy may need interest rates at “mildly supportive” levels to ensure inflation doesn’t fall below target after a series of shocks.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Jana Randow, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Pierre Wunsch

item.title: Nigeria Holds Key Rate Again Amid ‘Heightened Uncertainty’
item.description: The Central Bank of Nigeria left interest rates unchanged as it awaits more data to determine the inflation outlook and for the turbulence spawned by US President Donald Trump’s trade war to settle.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo, Ruth Olurounbi

media:content.media:description: Olayemi Cardoso

item.title: Canada Inflation Slows on Carbon Tax End, But Core Rises
item.description: Canadian inflation eased to its slowest pace since September on the elimination of the consumer carbon tax and lower oil prices, but core measures accelerated.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Shin, Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: A shopper browses a store in Toronto, Ontario. Photographer: Cole Burston/Bloomberg

item.title: White House’s Miran Dismisses Inflation Risk From Tariff Hikes
item.description: The White House’s chief economist dismissed the idea that tariff increases will have a lasting impact on US inflation, and cited the potential for interest rates to get back down to pre-Covid levels.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: Stephen Miran, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, speaks during the Hill & Valley forum at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, April 30, 2025. The Hill and Valley Forum, started in 2023, is a gathering of lawmakers and venture capitalists focused on the US technology industry.

item.title: Singapore Central Bank Chief Says US Dollar Assets Irreplaceable
item.description: Dollar-based assets have “enduring advantages” and remain virtually irreplaceable in the global financial system despite the US losing its top triple-A credit rating, according to Singapore’s central bank chief.
item.dc:creator: Claire Jiao

media:content.media:description: Chia Der Jiun

item.title: A Spendthrift Saudi Arabia Can’t Finance the World Anymore
item.description: Hello from Doha. I’m Erik Schatzker, editorial director of Bloomberg New Economy, bringing you a special edition of the newsletter from this year’s Qatar Economic Forum. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Erik Schatzker

item.title: India Lays Out Phased Timeline for US Trade Deal
item.description: India’s Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal is wrapping up a four-day visit to Washington on Tuesday, and he’s reporting “good discussions” with US officials on a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: Poste Italiane Could Be Partner for Digital Euro, Cipollone Says
item.description: Poste Italiane SpA could help introduce the digital euro to Italy, according to European Central Bank Executive Board member Piero Cipollone.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

media:content.media:description: The Euro symbol.

item.title: Turkey Sees ‘Huge’ Peace Dividend From End of $1.8 Trillion War
item.description: Turkey said it expects to reap “huge” economic gains from the Kurdish separatist group’s decision to stop its 40-year war in the country’s southeast.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: Mehmet Simsek Photographer: Karim Jafaar/Getty Images
